reviewText:
I Have played every Soul's/Borne (Platinated all except Demon Soul's) game and this one between my 2 favorites(Together with Demon's) .
After 2 weeks i have finally managed to complete all the achievements in this game and while doing so i have loved every single moment of this game.

Loved the design of the bosses ( even tough they're all pretty easy compared to all other soul's games (Except Nameless King that guy is one tough moda♥♥♥♥a)

The Pros of the game:

The Design of all of the level's: Every single map in this game is awesome in it's own form ( tough i didn't like High Wall all that much)

The Enemies are now alot harder: Normally the challenge of a game is it's bosses right? Wrong. in this one the bosses are easy and what stand's between you and them is the real challenge.

The Co-Op: I had a ♥♥♥♥♥ level 280 character and still managed to find some guys to help me out in Nameless in NG ++ and could find some PVP in Anor Londo still.

The Invasion's : Damn i never liked this part of the Soul's games before. guys hella stronger than you stalking around the boss area to cap your ♥♥♥ when you finally get there. But now everything is kind of balanced (Kind of) i managed to fight off 4 guys while on my way to one of the lords of cinder and some of then instead of ganking on you actually help when they think 3x1 is unfair.

Now the flaws i saw in this game( only 1 actually)

CONS: COVENANTS

Holy Hell. I have no words to describe it. With the exception of Mound Maker's (favorite of mine), Warrior of Sunlight and Rosaria's Finger's ( Invading so obviously) all other covenants are dead useless. DEAD.

Blade of the Darkmoon: Can only help Way of Blue. (Waited 3 hours in anor londo while i played on my PS4 to have a single invasion.

Blue Sentinel's: Ditto as the above

Way of Blue: only has players until the second or third area of the game and some rare ones later making the other 2 dead as hell.

Watchdogs of Farron : did a run on the game with this one on all the time untill abyss watchers (literally went through the whole area's gathering all items at level 35 waiting for an invasion ( Yes i was at Sacrifice Road) never had a single invasion.(Tough i was invaded so kudos for that not as dead)

Aldrich Faithful: Literally can only do it's thing in like 1% of game's area(from the area of a boss to the other wich is like 20 minutes of walk if you kill everything in your way and explore) but amazingly it is alive because of the pitfight's in the area( Power goes way up the head of some people i've seen some hot's using a whip and hitting the guys that didn't want to fight literally like he was the owner of the world).

CON 2: COVENANT'S PART 2.

Yeah.
Covenant's again.
Problem: as the 2 covenant's wich are to help way of blue are dead and dead as dead and dead( that's alot of dead) after the initial area's of the game you literally can't get rank's in those 2 without some HEAVY FARMING(BORING AS HELL) I Almost went into a Boringness induced coma farming the Proof of Concordt Kept to get the miracle and the ring.
And some people really think it's the fault of the players for not getting the damn 30 things before you get to level 40.(Nuts i know)

Apart from that farming of the other 2 went smooth ( Mound Maker's and Watchdog's of Farron) Mound Maker's i farmed at level 180 and still found people easily and Watchdog's is really easy to get the 30 killing some mobs in the swamp.
Aldrich Faithful is easy too.
So why the hell they did the hardest one and most boring one be the one that's the hardest one to find matches? Pure Evil? Satan advised those japanese to do it? probably but let's not get into that.

All in All i really liked this game. But if those 2 covenant's ( Blue Sentinel's and Darkmoon) actually worked without depending of a single covenant ( Like making Darkmoon work just like in Dark Soul's 1 wich would be the dream)
I would have been done with the 100% in about 30 hour's earlier ( I Just like to make 100% in soul's game's and i won't stop playing even now( i play dark soul's 1, 2 and Bloodborne all the time even to this day.

But even with that this game get's about 99% of my love so this review will be a positive one.

reviewText:
Alright, serious review time.

Dark Souls 3 is the best in the series. Yeah, I said it. Am I alone in that opinion? Perhaps, but I'll say it anyway.

The easiest way to describe Dark Souls 3 is to tell you that From Software looked at all the Souls games, including Demons Souls, and said, lets take what we did best in each of these and combine it".

And it worked out beautifully. DS3 has all the atmosphere and subtlety of Demons Souls
date: it has the memorable characters and incredible world of Dark Souls
recommended: and it has the refined mechanics and covenant diversity of Dark Souls 2. Well and there's even some inspiration from Bloodborne thrown in for good measure. The game is a love song to the fans of the series
hoursPlayed: and its extremely evident that the team put their heart into this game. They didn't make Dark Souls 3 for the money
voteText: they made Dark Souls 3 for the love of the series.\n\nDS3 does introduce some mechanics of its own
helpfulPercent: as well. The weapon upgrade system from Demons Souls returns
votesHelpful: but is combined with the upgrade system from DS2. How so? Well
votesTotal: there's a plethora of upgrade paths once more
votesFunny: including the long desired Quality
commentsCount: but each path uses the same basic materials with gems to "infuse" the weapon. Spell uses are gone now
column16: replaced by the MP bar from Demons Souls (now called FP) and Attunement increases this bar as well as your spell slots. "Dual" weapons exist now and become dual wielded when two-handed
column17: functionally working like powerstancing in Dark Souls 2.\n\nBut theres a lot thats new to see here and to just list it all off isn't terribly important. Thats what wikis are for. So now we're gonna talk about the story and atmosphere of the game. And yes
column18: major spoilers will be abound.\n\nI'll say it again
column19:
SPOILERS BELOW.


Its not unusual for a Souls game to invoke emotion in the player. Hell
column20: when I fought Garl Vinland in Demons Souls I felt no sense of accomplishment. Only sorrow. But no Souls game yet has made me simply *feel* as often as Dark Souls 3 has. The moment I entered the Firelink Shrine
column21: nostalgia washed over me. Here before me was the familiar Nexus of Demons Souls
column22: but different. And then the Fire Keeper spoke almost the very same words the Maiden in Black said to me seven years ago. It was a lot to take in
column23: and it was only the beginning. Wandering further into the shrine I heard a familiar hammer
column24: and saw a familiar face. Andre of Astora
column25: still alive after all these years.\n\nIt didn't stop there. I made my way through the game
column26: fighting tooth and nail to survive and emerged into Irithyll
column27: the Boreal Valley. It was tough
column28: but I got through that too. As I walked out of that place
column29: a sense of familiarity washed over me again. There were knights with greatbows firing at me as I dashed across the rooftop to safety
column30: emerging in a room all too familiar: the Darkmoon Tomb. I couldn't believe it
column31: I thought it was a mere homage to DS1. I ran out of the room and pulled the elevator lever excitedly. I had to know
column32: I had to see it. I spun the lever once more and ascended. And there it was
column33: Anor Londo. I was back.\n\nI don't want to talk about every single emotional moment
column34: there were far too many. I'll just share one more. The final battle. Entering the Kiln of the First Flame was in itself another emotional moment
column35: but it didn't truly hit me until the fight began. The Soul of Cinder swung a mighty weapon and wielded powerful spells
column36: but it meant nothing until the second phase of the fight
column37: when the moveset and the music changed. Then the realization hit me. You see
column39: a familiar piano began to play
column40: a familiar greatsword was swung. The Soul of Cinder wasn't some random guardian that From cooked up to give me one last challenge. The Soul of Cinder was me in Dark Souls 1. The Soul of Cinder was you. The Soul of Cinder was Gwyn. It was everyone who had linked the fire. This was very well the end of the series
column41: and the final challenge to overcome was none other than my former self.\n\nSo why am I gushing about all these emotional moments in a review? This is a video game right? Well
column43: this is in all likelihood the final Souls game. It was made for people like me
column44: who have been with the series since Demons Souls. Who felt no joy in defeating Garl Vinland
column45: who felt a solemn respect and pity for the husk that once was Gwyn. This was for us. Thats why these moments matter. For us
column46: Souls games make us feel. And that Dark Souls 3 makes me feel as much as it does is very important.\n\nSo thats it. I've sung the game's praises enough. If this is to be the last hurrah of my beloved series
column47: I am completely okay with that. This is the perfect end to a series that has meant so much to me. It was a wonderful journey
column48: I'm glad to have been a part of it."

reviewText:
This review comes from a offline playthrough, as I prefer a single player experience like with every game I play. But especially with heavy mooded games like the Souls series I prefer to be completely immersed without being distracted by online traffic. Also this is just my first playthrough, so I'm probably missing a million things. Having said that I can say the following about my experience:

+ Graphically this game is sublime, absolutely beautiful. Textures are rich and detailed, background and lighting are very atmospheric. Very happy to see as much beautiful medieval fantasy architecture (both interior and exterior) as there is.
+ Not only that, it also runs very smoothly (at least on my system) and I have encounterd little to no bugs on my 80+ hours of play.
+ Combat is satisfying and fluent. There are some great movesets, it's pretty hard to choose a bad weapon here (as long as your build is suitable for it ofcourse).
+ Some boss desings are awesome as ever (not all quite as surprising as in DS1, but some really are)
+ I like the collection of characters you get to meet and the story they carry with them. There are a couple of really enjoyable storylines to follow throughout the game, making it a very replayable (NG+) experience.
+ The number of weapons, armor and other loot is also very impressive
+ The way leveling works took a little bit time to get used to, but in the end I liked it, it's fun to play around and see what works best for you.
+ Good variety of characters and playstyles to choose from
+ Locations feel fun and varied, although some may not like the reusage of former game locations and formerly valuable key items being (at least seemingly, I might be missing something) casually thrown in a dusty corner and reduced to mere non-essential decorative trinkets. I think the rehash has been done in a nice and respectable way, but then again I never played Bloodborne or DS2 and only the first part of Demon Souls so I probably recognised less and interprated more elements as something new.

- I don't like the idea of Fire Link as a central hub. It has its advantages, but it very much makes the world feel less naturally connected. What I absolutely love about DS1 is the way the levels connect with eachother and the freedom of movement you've got to navigate between them both back and forth. Every place you see is reachable, you can walk right to it (except for the asylum at the beginning, but that was a deliberate and thought out decision, it makes sense).
Here from the very start you can't reach Lothric without poofing from one bonfire to another. And you need to poof back to get back to Firelink Shrine, no walking allowed. To me this makes it a destination without a solid, touchable place in the game world, even though you can look upon it from afar from certain points of view.
- Also in general there are way too many bonfires too close to each other, reducing the challenge and breaking immersion\sense of urgency in exchange for more focus on combat and faster pacing. They might as well have made a quicksave option at this point.
- Many of the characters in this hub seem to have too little variation in the lines they say as you progress in the game. Especially the Fire Keeper which whom you have to talk to most because you can't just level up at a bonfire anymore. There are some surprising lines and lore to discover, but I think there could have been more (hell, there isn't even a why-did-you-ran-away-without-saying-bye line this time around). I know for sure I have missed some by the decisions I've made in this playthrough, so I hope to discover more on next playthroughs.
- I haven't found a use for the repairing system yet. My armor never wore off and neither did my weapons. I must be missing something here, or at least I hope I am.

All and all DS3 is a great experience and I would highly recommend it. To me it's not as fresh and original as DS1, but that doesn't mean it's not an awesome, challenging and satisfying game. When all the hype has been done hyping and maybe the cheating system will be fixed I'll go for a online run, but it's already been fun enough.

reviewText:
To put it simply, Dark Souls III is a phenomenal game. Not a perfect one, despite what me giving it a ten may say. If I were to give it a more accurate score, I'd personally give it a 9.4. It brings back a lot of elements from the first Dark Souls, and the level designs really do feel like I'm in a different version of Lordran. Whenever I see the sweeping castles in the distance, I can't help but be reminded of Anor Londo. And traversing the High Wall of Lothric just feels so much like traversing the high ledges of Undead Parish, it's just...nostalgic and refreshing at the same time. Even the cliffs in the Cemetery of Ash up to Firelink Shrine remind me of the cliffs surrounding the original Firelink Shrine, as well as the graveyard surrounding The Catacombs. It truly is like a love letter to the series, as well as to the fans who have been with the series since the start.

Moving on to the gameplay aspects, combat is much faster now (you can thank Bloodborne for that), and there's a new element to it that has been added, in the form of Weapon Arts (I think that's what they're called). These function as special techniques that change based on the weapon you happen to be using, and deal high damage at the cost of a new uh...I'm not really sure what to call it, but it functions similarly to health (you even get a unique Estus Flask to refill it). I don't know the actual name, but it's referred to as FP, and a little is drained every time you use a Weapon Art. There's also a 'Cinder Mode' where you have double health and I believe increased strength until death. You can achieve this by either killing a boss, or using a consumable item known as an Ember.

And all those pesky annoyances about Hollowing, such as losing some of your max health, as well as now looking like a zombie, are gone. When you die, you just lose all of your Souls and are sent back to the last bonfire. No Health loss, no green skin, none of that. If I'm not mistaken, death functions similarly to Bloodborne in that aspect.

I will close with a slight warning. The PC version has occasional framerate dips. Fortunately, at least for me, they didn't interrupt play too much, and I was still plenty able to enjoy my time with the game despite these dips.

All in all, I absolutely love this game. It's fantastic, it really, really is.

reviewText:
I've played through Dark Salad's first two installments, though I'm not a massive fan of the series. That being said, here's my spiel on the third installment:
From is one of those publishers who apparently really like to reuse their formula for gameplay. This is by no means a bad thing, especially since it works here. Overall, the movement for the player and for the varying sizes of flesh in this installment feels way less stiff from previous games. Movements feel faster and more fluid, allowing for combat to be way more intimate over previous installments where the stratagem was usally just to wait for Bigbritches McBossalot to do a heavy attack so you have time to peck at his ankles. The one place this falters, and feel free to tell me I'm wrong about this, is with shields that have 100% physical block. In my opinion, these things make Dark Sutra games way too easy, as only a handful of enemies have alternate means of damage.

The enviornment of this game is something to behold. Many of the areas (save for some out of bounds nonsense, as per usual) are marvelously crafted and mind-bendingly interwoven. It's truly something to visit the other half of a destroyed bridge hours of meandering around later. Something I kind of hated about Dark Souls One was the amount of depressing caves and dark areas that were visually akin to hard pudding. There's a lot less of that here, and environments of that sort are better crafted this time around.

All I can really say about PvP from my lack of expecience in prior games and lack of a pretentious state of mind is that it's a lot easier to have fun with it if you're new to the series. Being bad is totally fine, because odds are you'll have like 3+ dudes with you engaged in jolly cooperation anyway.

Class rebalancing is pretty solid. Weapon stances are a welcome change to make melee combat seem less mundane. The same can be said for spells. Good God there are a lot of magic and faith options this time around--both in gear and in heathen spellcasting. There's so many that I'd even say that the devs clearly favored all classes having at least a bit of every category, because as Strength BigCubberhousen I feel that I'm missing out on quite a lot.

Lastly, and this can be a good thing or a bad thing, Dark Souls Tres really, REALLY wants you to remember the first two games. There are so damn many references through bosses, enemies, equipment, areas, and everything else that are about the first two games, mostly Dark Souls One. I honestly feel that they overdid it a bit, because the game feels less like its own thing and more like a reimagining of the first installment. To this end, you might actually enjoy the game more if you haven't played previous installments.

Overall, I'd say this game is worth your time if adventure games are your thing, casual or not. Given the game's resources for the player, these games really aren't as hard as they're infamously said to be. In fact, I'd say they do difficulty extraordinarily well, as encounters are engaging and require you to think quite a lot more than most other modern games, at least that I have played. Murdering those big bosses for the first time really feels like an achievement, and to me that makes the game well worth what I paid for it.

In summary: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ZvbN4MXQDM

reviewText:
This is my first Dark Souls game, and I am hooked. It provides a challenge not many people can handle, and it actually takes time to progress, but while you progress in game, your skill improves. Don't get me wrong, it's difficult, but its deliciously difficult, and I wouldn't want it any other way. I can't remember having the same patience I have had for this game, for any other game I have played.

The graphics are phenomenal, and the developers did a great job at creating the enviornments, and the enemies that reside within the Dark Souls 3 world. I can run everyone on max, and it looks stunning.

The online play is a great feature, and finding people to team up with to work together or to help out, is very simple and effective.

With the ability to fully customize your character, not only visually but skill point wise, it makes each character experience more unique. Want to be a brute warrior with a huge sword? Go ahead. Want to wield magic and deal ranged damage at a safer distance? Go ahead. Want to wield that huge club while also being able to throw a few fireballs? Go ahead. You have endless potential to play the game the way you want to.

Enough of review reading, get out there and collect souls!

reviewText:
This review comes from a offline playthrough, as I prefer a single player experience like with every game I play. But especially with heavy mooded games like the Souls series I prefer to be completely immersed without being distracted by online traffic. Also this is just my first playthrough, so I'm probably missing a million things. Having said that I can say the following about my experience:

+ Graphically this game is sublime, absolutely beautiful. Textures are rich and detailed, background and lighting are very atmospheric. Very happy to see as much beautiful medieval fantasy architecture (both interior and exterior) as there is.
+ Not only that, it also runs very smoothly (at least on my system) and I have encounterd little to no bugs on my 80+ hours of play.
+ Combat is satisfying and fluent. There are some great movesets, it's pretty hard to choose a bad weapon here (as long as your build is suitable for it ofcourse).
+ Some boss desings are awesome as ever (not all quite as surprising as in DS1, but some really are)
+ I like the collection of characters you get to meet and the story they carry with them. There are a couple of really enjoyable storylines to follow throughout the game, making it a very replayable (NG+) experience.
+ The number of weapons, armor and other loot is also very impressive
+ The way leveling works took a little bit time to get used to, but in the end I liked it, it's fun to play around and see what works best for you.
+ Good variety of characters and playstyles to choose from
+ Locations feel fun and varied, although some may not like the reusage of former game locations and formerly valuable key items being (at least seemingly, I might be missing something) casually thrown in a dusty corner and reduced to mere non-essential decorative trinkets. I think the rehash has been done in a nice and respectable way, but then again I never played Bloodborne or DS2 and only the first part of Demon Souls so I probably recognised less and interprated more elements as something new.

- I don't like the idea of Fire Link as a central hub. It has its advantages, but it very much makes the world feel less naturally connected. What I absolutely love about DS1 is the way the levels connect with eachother and the freedom of movement you've got to navigate between them both back and forth. Every place you see is reachable, you can walk right to it (except for the asylum at the beginning, but that was a deliberate and thought out decision, it makes sense).
Here from the very start you can't reach Lothric without poofing from one bonfire to another. And you need to poof back to get back to Firelink Shrine, no walking allowed. To me this makes it a destination without a solid, touchable place in the game world, even though you can look upon it from afar from certain points of view.
- Also in general there are way too many bonfires too close to each other, reducing the challenge and breaking immersion\sense of urgency in exchange for more focus on combat and faster pacing. They might as well have made a quicksave option at this point.
- Many of the characters in this hub seem to have too little variation in the lines they say as you progress in the game. Especially the Fire Keeper which whom you have to talk to most because you can't just level up at a bonfire anymore. There are some surprising lines and lore to discover, but I think there could have been more (hell, there isn't even a why-did-you-ran-away-without-saying-bye line this time around). I know for sure I have missed some by the decisions I've made in this playthrough, so I hope to discover more on next playthroughs.
- I haven't found a use for the repairing system yet. My armor never wore off and neither did my weapons. I must be missing something here, or at least I hope I am.

All and all DS3 is a great experience and I would highly recommend it. To me it's not as fresh and original as DS1, but that doesn't mean it's not an awesome, challenging and satisfying game. When all the hype has been done hyping and maybe the cheating system will be fixed I'll go for a online run, but it's already been fun enough.

reviewText:
==== Review ====First Impression
As a Dark Souls newbie, this game was extremely punishing at first and tested my patience to the next level. Never have I been forced to stop spamming dodge/attack and actually learn the moveset of the boss or perfect my reaction time. It took me approximately 2 hours to beat Iudex as a starting Mercenary, but the thrill and adrenaline post-battle was truly something no other game offered. I never thought I could come to love a game that wanted to kill me so badly.

Gameplay
As I fought my way through the story, I began to become immersed with the lore and progression system. Bonfires are placed just when you truly need them most. Enemies are never too difficult - strong enough to warrant consistent player attention. Although the world design is fairly spectacular, it was mostly linear/bi-linear (city with a dungeon below it) with moderate exploration required for completionists. The traditionally grande map comprised of interconnecting smaller maps through shortcuts is replaced with a more direct route. However, the world is still HUGE. 19 total bosses with several mini-bosses in between. The extremely well planned level and boss design (minus a couple bosses) easily makes DS III the most memorable game I have ever played. I can clearly recount most of the paths in every area along with every bosses' movesets and shenanigans.

==== Current State of the Game ====Issues & Updates
DS III launched with quite a few minor grievances, mostly sporatic FPS drops, but all of them have been fixed. The only major issue atm is regarding softbanning due to Data Inconsistencies" which may occur due to advancing in the game offline (de-syncing with the server) or from online hackers. Continuous patches have been applied since the posting of this review in order to keep up to date with the demanding pvp balance and bug encounters.

==== Conclusion ====Verdict
I can't stress enough how much I really enjoyed playing DS III. I really regret never playing the earlier two during their hayday
date:
but at least it gives me something to do while i lament the end of this great journey.

Masterpiece
- 10/10"

This game, is everything i've hoped for, it's simply amazing, no videogame is perfect, but this game is coming damn ♥♥♥♥ing close. The game could, and should be summed up with but one word ''Masterpiece''
Dark souls, which is arguably the best videogame series ever made, changed how i looked at videogames forever. the sheer detail and work that was put into it is astonishing. this was also the saddest  playthrough of a game i ever had, constantly being reminded that this is the last one, the last time i can ever experience a masterpiece like this.

The fire fades, and with it, so does dark souls. it's brave and beautiful. in dark souls we heard that the flame was dying out, in dark souls 2, the flame was still burning. but now, it's dead. the flame, the series, and the universe has come to an end. after this, there is nothing, no deus ex machina to save the day, no more hope. simply an empty void in which nothing leaves but a trace of what once was.
That's truly the hardest thing about dark souls, and at least miyazaki kept his word. The series went out with a bang, For me, this is the best game i've ever played. i don't want to spoil anything so the only thing i can say is, please, please, for ♥♥♥♥'s sake, play this game, play this game and be amazed. there is nothing else like it, and nothing like it will ever come again.

reviewText:
Much like the first Dark Souls, this game is difficult and requires a lot of patience to down the epic and challenging bosses and the, sometimes, much stronger enemies.
The fact that Dark Souls III returns to the roots of Dark Souls (and Demon's Souls to a lesser extent) is incredibly exciting and I had an awesome time playing this installment. As someone who struggles to stay interested in a game for longer than a couple of hours, I've got 100+ hours clocked into DS3 and I still want to play more.

A lot of my opinion on the game is based on PvE and PvE Coop (both matchmaking and password, which is a godsend), as the majority of the PvP I've done is either a pretty good matchmaking experience or I've used a password to be summoned by friends for a friendly duel. I have not experienced any issues with the online thus far, apart from a few summons being timed out, however this usually only happens once.

As with DS1, the hack 'n' slash action-RPG style gameplay is what entices me the most and allows plenty of replayability using different builds and equipment. The leveling system is the key to wielding higher-tier weapons and it feels so satisfying to come back to difficult enemies in the earlier areas to slaughter them in revenge.

Dark Souls III is easily one of my favourite games so far of 2016 and I'm highly anticipating the upcoming DLC.

In regards to my game time and saying I have 100+ hours clocked"
date: I spent about 80-90 hours on a pirated copy before I was able to afford the game. I have no regrets buying the game as I believe FROM has done an outstanding job and they deserve my money as I've enjoyed this game quite a lot. I just thought I'd write this for anyone who cares."

reviewText:
At currently just over 100 hours in the game, I can say with confidence that I do enjoy it. Keeping things short, I will just list some pros and cons. This is by no means a conclusive review, but these are the things that stood out to me.

- Enviroments are wonderful to look at and explore. While most areas within themselves are pretty non-linear, the ways that the areas connect to each other seem very linear, with few exceptions.

- The lack of power stances, while annyoing, seems to be replaced by weapon abilites. These abilities do add some awesome depth, and many unique weapons and shields have unique abilities. This is on top of the large amount of unique weapons and armor that you can find in the game.

- Hitboxes in this game seem far more accurate than the second game. The moments when you dodge hard hitting boss attacks just by sidestepping attacks is far more satisfying than constantly having to dodge huge invisible weapon hitboxes. Combat is tighter than ever in this title, making PvP all the more enjoyable.

- While some areas in the game feel cheap as f^*&, everything is surmountable. It just makes the feeling of satisfaction all the more palpable.

reviewText:
I'm most likely near the end of the game and I can safely say this is my favorite game of the series (and I'm a huge fan of souls).

The areas and bosses are fantastic and unique, the new additions to combat (weapon arts, focus, etc.) add a lot more strategy and depth, and the difficulty and progression feels just right. I feel that this is the toughest souls game to date, yet it never feels blatantly unfair.

It really feels like they took the best parts of their previous games and rolled it into one amazing package.

This game has made me have :-

-Trust issues (Mad phantoms)
-Anger issues (Chuggers, gankers and pimptiff sullyvan)
-Paranoia (Invaders man.. they.. they live in the boxes man.)

Pros :-

- Amazing combat in both PvE and PvP
- Imersive story that will grab you instantly
- Infuriating bosses that will make you their ♥♥♥♥♥
- Wide variety of weapons and magic
- Thousands of hours of game play
- Amazing community

Cons :-

- ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BOSSES THAT MAKE YOU THEIR ♥♥♥♥♥
- Unbalanced weapons such as Long swords and rapiers *Cough* Dark sword, Estoc *Cough* and painfully bad magic which does close to no damage.
- From Soft arn't good with the community. Softbans to undeserving players, saying poise is working when it's evidentily not and, like I said before, unbalanced weapons.
- Some of the covenants arn't working well such as the way of the blue, covenant which summons you in to a world to save the hosts ♥♥♥.
- Can only have a max of 10 charaters
- You will die.. a lot.

Conclusion :-

Dark souls is hard as ♥♥♥♥ but is the most rewarding game I have ever played. Yes it has flaws such as balance issues. bugs and poor devs but if you want a game that will make you work for your glory. Fun, fast paced and filled with diverse builds Dark Souls III is worth every penny.

reviewText:
TL;DR at bottom

First off, I want to say that this is the first and only Dark Souls game I have ever played, and I went in only knowing of the games very hard difficulty.

I have to say, this is without a doubt the best action/adventure game I have ever played, without a doubt. Most every aspect of this game is enjoyable, in a frusterating way.

This game is also one of the most rewarding games I have ever played, this game will kick you when you are down, and you will have to try and do everything to get your place (and your souls) back. But once you do, you taste the sweet revenge that you were seeking, which fuels you to play for another two more hours.

I just finished the game, and it took me about 50 hours, and that is just for the very first save, now that I have beat the game, I have the option of playing NG+, which allows me to play through the game with my character, but with a new story. Mind blowing.

I would reccommend this game wholeheartedly to anyone who enjoys a great game that they can sit down and play for hours at a time.

But there is also one thing that I would like to touch on...

Although, the multiplayer aspect of the game is interesting, it is also quite flawed.

The idea behind the multiplayer is nice, you can put down a summon scroll and help someone else in their world, or if you want to play with a friend, you can put on a password and summon them. That is awesome! Although you require consumables to spawn in people (which I personally don't like), that is fine.

But the invasions in the game are very annoying. You are forced to go into someone else's world, and fight them, for barely anything in return, and this can happen at most any time assuming you are playing with online enabled.

This also happens when you are playing with friends, up to two people can come into your world, disrupt what you are doing, and destroy you, completely halting your progress. This is without a doubt very annoying, and although it is a small flaw in an otherwise flawless game, the flaw is very very bad in my opinion.

TL;DR: Best Action/Adventure game I have ever played, this game is amazing! If you have friends, I would reccommend you and them pick this up and play with eachother, or solo for that matter. Multiplayer is slightly flawed, but beyond that I couldn't reccommend this game enough!

9/10

reviewerDisplayName: B E H E M O T H
reviewText:
The first Dark Souls was among my top three favorite games of all time and this game may have topped it. The environments are all varied and gorgeous, the combat feels amazing and the new weapon art system adds a new layer of depth.

The game is difficult. Of course that is subjective, but in my experience I had a fairly difficult time with at least half the bosses, a select few taking over ten tries each.

But, most importantly, there are the bosses. In my opinion there were no bad bosses in this game at all. Each boss now has a first and second stage which creates some of the best boss fights that i've experienced in video games.

Last but definitely not least is the soundtrack. Some of the tracks may not be as memorable as some of the ones in the original Dark Souls but especially once you get to the later game content it will blow you away. Everything from epic choirs chanting, violins, horns and there's even a harpsichord in some of the pieces. One of the pieces has the harpsichord as it's main instrument which you barely see these days.

All in all, this is definetly one of my favorite games of all time. I'd recommend it to anyone willing to git gud" and veterans of the series will feel right at home. A solid 10 out of 10."

reviewText:
This review comes from a player who have never got banned or came across a hacker after more than 100h playtime

About the Reviewer
Overall Dark Souls Experience
My name is Gal and I am a huge fan of the   Dark Souls	 game searies. I strated playing the first game out of the three in 2013 and finished it twice (on PC and on XBOX 360). While playing  Dark Souls 1	 I became obsessed with the game and loved every single thing about it. Then, in 2014  Dark Souls 2	 was born and a new saga began to the  Dark Souls	 searies. I have played the second game the second it came out and I finished it a week after, and to be honest, it wasn't a blast. I had fun time playing it, but it was just not like the first game.
And then, Dark Souls 3	 showed himself to the world in 2016...........

Current State in Dark Souls 3
In the middle of the second playtrough with a new character. Playing a lot of PvP with the first character after finishing the game and grinding to level 120 (PvP Meta).

My Opinion
First Cutcene
When I launched the game for the first time I was so happy to go back into the world of  Dark Souls	, the menu screen, the sounds, everything was exactly like good old  Dark Souls	. Then, the first cutscene started (and with it the goosebumps ^^) and god.... oh god the voice acting in this game is just... SO ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ GOOD! Already in the first cutscene you hear an old woman's voice telling you about the history of a place called  Lothric	 and while hearing the woman's voice you see characters and lords that you know, you are going to meet and probably fight.

First Gameplay and Boss Impression
The gameplay starts, and you pick up your Ashen Flask after killing a bunch of dudes and then you light the first bonefire, wasn't so hard right? Meeting the first boss 2 second later gives you that breathtaking feeling that you are fighting against a gigantic armored guy that got some cool moves. After few tries you manage to take him down to half health and you see  phase 2	, and oh god, that is just terrifying!  Some dark creature is just cracking his way up from that guy	 and you need to fight against it! After managing to take that thing down you fully walk into.... the world of Dark Souls 3!

40 Hours Into the Game
You are geared up, got your own playstyle with unique swords and spells and you crawl deeper into the dark lore meeting up glorious and scary bosses. In your journey you get to choose things that will affect the end that you will get (  there are 3 endings to the game and another special end	 ) and to be honest, on my first playthrough, I didn't knew what I was actualy picking (Blind playthrough) but at the end I figured it out.

Overall Rating
Story: 8/10 - 	 I realy love the  Dark Souls	 franchise lore (the things I know about it...) but I didn't like it so much how the developers delivered it in the third game. there are a lot of NPC questline that you most likely missed on your first playthrough and how the lore is being told... it is too foggy in my opinion.

Sounds (Music and Voice Acting) : 10/10 -  The music in this game just matches so good into some situations and the voice acting is amazing.

Gameplay and Mechanics  (Xbox 360 Controller) : 9/10 - 	I realy enjoyed how the game is being played and the new weapon arts is just great. I was sad to see that they took down the dual wielding stance and some of the mechanics are just hiddin inside the game and you only realise them when watching a toutorial or by accident.

PvP and Online Matchmaking: 8/10 -	  Dark Souls 3	 is the first Dark Souls game I started playing PvP and I having super fun with it. The problem is that some of the weapons are just not balanced enough and the hitbox can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ sometimes.

Graphics and Sceneries: 10/10 - 	The game looks great and most of the sceneries are so amazingly good (  Irithyll of the boreal valley	 was just so beautiful ).


This was my first review, hope you guys liked it :)

reviewText:
==== Review ====First Impression
As a Dark Souls newbie, this game was extremely punishing at first and tested my patience to the next level. Never have I been forced to stop spamming dodge/attack and actually learn the moveset of the boss or perfect my reaction time. It took me approximately 2 hours to beat Iudex as a starting Mercenary, but the thrill and adrenaline post-battle was truly something no other game offered. I never thought I could come to love a game that wanted to kill me so badly.

Gameplay
As I fought my way through the story, I began to become immersed with the lore and progression system. Bonfires are placed just when you truly need them most. Enemies are never too difficult - strong enough to warrant consistent player attention. Although the world design is fairly spectacular, it was mostly linear/bi-linear (city with a dungeon below it) with moderate exploration required for completionists. The traditionally grande map comprised of interconnecting smaller maps through shortcuts is replaced with a more direct route. However, the world is still HUGE. 19 total bosses with several mini-bosses in between. The extremely well planned level and boss design (minus a couple bosses) easily makes DS III the most memorable game I have ever played. I can clearly recount most of the paths in every area along with every bosses' movesets and shenanigans.

==== Current State of the Game ====Issues & Updates
DS III launched with quite a few minor grievances, mostly sporatic FPS drops, but all of them have been fixed. The only major issue atm is regarding softbanning due to Data Inconsistencies" which may occur due to advancing in the game offline (de-syncing with the server) or from online hackers. Continuous patches have been applied since the posting of this review in order to keep up to date with the demanding pvp balance and bug encounters.

==== Conclusion ====Verdict
I can't stress enough how much I really enjoyed playing DS III. I really regret never playing the earlier two during their hayday
date:
but at least it gives me something to do while i lament the end of this great journey.

Masterpiece
- 10/10"

reviewText:
I am having nothing but problems with this port. I thought after several weeks/months these issues would have been resolved, but even at low settings I am frequently dropping to 12-15 fps. To make matters worse, the game won't allow you to play in online mode with a low framerate. Your game session also terminates if your framerate falls too far. The entire UI is obviously designed for console users, and there isn't even a quit to desktop function. You have to exit from the main menu.

Other than that, the game is itself is pretty fun. The difficulty is what you would expect, and the sword play is faster than Dark Souls II.

I just can't recommend the game due to its bugginess. I shouldn't be getting drops like this on a 390x.

reviewText:
The first of the three games of the Dark Souls trilogy I would actually recommend.

Why?
The first two games were poorly ported for the PC.

The pre-review:

The first being an overall frame rate nightmare, only maxing out at 30fps (which the game was made to max out at 30fps). And the online play was really wonky, which made a huge negative impact on my review of it. The story of the player's journey made it a memorable experience though.

The second game fixed the frame rate, maxing out at 60fps, which made for a much smoother game. The problem is, the multiplayer was still really messed up, it allowed messages and blood pools to be accessed, but no online help during boss fights. And the bosses were totally unoriginal, many having similar characteristics to either another boss in DS1, or even another boss in the same game. The second game also removed the dark, creepy atmosphere which really killed the game. DS2, in my OPINION, was the worst of the series and the worst game I've played in years mainly because the health system.

The Review of Dark Souls III:

I absolutely LOVE this game! It is everything the first two games tried to be, but not without its flaws, of course. They have improved multiplayer connectivity, making for easy summoning. A flaw to this though is that the area I am currently in, I can't be embered and take more than two steps without being invaded (If you are looking into buying the game, you probably don't know what ember is, if you've played the first game, it is similar to humanity, or the second game's human effigies. If you ember, it increases your health to max, adding about 25% more to the bar. It also allows you to summon other players and get invaded) The boss fights are actually fun again.

My favorite thing to do is help people get past bosses. I've been helping so many people get past the tree boss fight in undead settlement.

If you want to know, my character name is Lord Kool Kat, so if you raid me, make sure to say hi first!!!

Also, please, if you are a mage build, don't be a total c*nt... What I mean by that is, don't hide yourself in a big group of enemies just so you don't get your *** kicked. It is cheap and annoying.

Huge tip for new players:
Round your character out. I suggest starting as either a knight or a warrior and then learning magic and all that. It will help in the long run!

reviewText:
...There are so many issues with this Dark Souls, it needs DLC to fix.

PVP is generally in a poor state. Poise isn't just turned off, that'd be nice. They could fix that. Poise is an almost useless stat that effectively makes a full havels user with 69.9 weight ratio, a tower shield and a wolf ring...The most agile character in the game.

Weapons are pretty pisspoor balanced, and currently you have a god-tier. An 'okay but why' tier, and a huge mass of junk. Junk includes all magic that's not pyromancy as well. And all ranged weapons. Its sad when I feel like throwing knives are...better then a bow or crossbow.

The game's high points are early with few exceptions. (Farron Keep felt like the last...really awesome and exciting area...and HIgh Wall of Lothric...the first actual zone, is the most difficult of the lot. Somehow.)

The game is extraordinarily linear. With two total 'branches', and in addition a grand total of two 'sideroutes', one is a brief Demon Ruin zone...that somehow makes hte original Demon Ruins look like fun.

The other is... King's Gardens (or something like that) a tiny, tiny area. Untended Graves (The neatest of the optional areas, led to by King's Gardens...but it's also tiny as...its smaller than the tutorial zone.)

And finally, Archdragon Peak. an actual decent sized zone that's I guess kind of a weird Sen's Fortress but meh area. Its only distinct as alot of people die to it. It's mostly useful for farming crafting components and souls. Basically having whole areas expressly set up to enable that. Its okay, though. Not bad. Decent area, if unremarkable. The boss has a great track for it though.

The game...Dark Souls 3 I can't reccomend right now. In total. It's a mess. Its filled with cheaters, bugs and broken issues. I thought DkS2 was dissapointing until Scholars launched. I thought it was pretty much an awful mess. Then came DkS3. I don't know. I'm pretty unhappy so far--I reccomend, it, likely, in the future. If From actually works on it.

reviewText:
My Dark Souls III Review(as of 78 hours playtime)

This game is an absolute gem, and the perfect way to close the Dark Souls series. I truly don't believe From Software could've done it any better. Playing it for the 3rd time round, still absolutely adore this game <3

Pro's
Addictively good questline
Flexible levelling system
Best bosses in the series (in my opinion)
Great travelling system
Awesome integration of shortcuts and checkpoints
Genius level design
Fantastic use of optional areas
Sexual levels of nostalgia
Con's
Somewhat frequent frame drops
Sometimes underwhelming boss fights
That's literally f*cking it go buy it now
Even if you've never played a Dark Souls game before (including bloodborne/demon souls), you will adore this game to bits if you have the courage and determination to keep going. Some may say it's too difficult"

Not only that but the developers could not be bothered to bind the keys for PC properly or even change the default Xbox keys to actual PC keys. They quite literally ported it by the looks of it without touching a single thing.

Would hugely not recommend this game.

reviewText: (Note that this review was written not a month after the game's release, so certain point may no longer be relevant...as if anyone cared)\n\nAfter playing Dark Souls 1 and 2 for a total of more than one thousand hours, I think I can freely say that Dark Souls 3 truly is the grand finale" the series deserved. It basically retrieved and improved the best aspects from the previous games
date: and took care of the bad ones
recommended: creating the perfect mix beetwen the two.\n\nThe biggest improvements were made in combat
hoursPlayed: and with combat being the most important aspect in the game
voteText: that's a damn good thing.\nThe biggest innovation is the introduction of "Skills" AKA "Weapon Arts". Those are special attacks with unique properties
helpfulPercent: specific to each weapon type (for example. straight swords let you perform attack that breaks the enemy's guard when blocking
votesHelpful: allowing for devastating critical attack). Those are of various usefulness though (patches may fix that)
votesTotal: but still
votesFunny: they provide new interesting options during combat.\nThe combat in general is much faster than it was in previous releases. The attacks are swifter
commentsCount: deal more damage
column16: and require more finesse to use. Backstabbing and parrying mechanics are much more intuitive and are more based on skill and timing
column17: rather than luck and "fishing" (alternatively
column18: using lag to your advantage).\nOther than that
column19: the combat is largely the way it was before
column20: without special revelations.\n\nThere are still certain issues with game balance that weren't taken care of
column21: however. Swift weapons
column22: such as rapiers and straight swords
column23: are still the bane of most players
column24: since all it takes to defeat your enemy is spamming the same attack over and over again. A common tactics is buffing such weapon with magic and watching your enemy die in agony
column25: locked in an endless barrage of swift hits. While veteran players know how to counter it quite reliably
column26: new players are pretty much helpless against it and have no real chance of winning.\n\nAside from that
column27: it's still the same old Dark Souls we know and love/hate
column28: so there's no point in detailing the rest. The game is still surrounded by that peculiar aura of mystery and despair. The soundtrack is amazing once again
column30: charming NPCs you will definitely grow attached to.\n\nMy only issue with the game is that it's too short. Completing it takes about 20 hours
column31: which is half the time it would take fo finish the first game. But that will definitely change when they release the DLCs
column32: and the replay value already more than makes up for the short length of the game.\nWhile I think Dark Souls 3 is superior to Dark Souls 2

reviewText: At the time of posting this, the cheating that's going on it this game is still an issue. Both valve(I understand they don't have to) and fromSoft refuse to do anything about the cheaters who have been running around in this game. Having put in a ticket with both steam and bamco about this I basically got a whole lot of f*uck you in response. Cheats since last I played outside of 5 mins ago to see if anything changed(well over a month ago at this point) fake phantoms that serve as dmg sponges, the usual infinite health/stamina, and the most annoying of all being one that will actually get you softbanned by fromSoft. These are still a thing. What makes it so bad was that these cheats started popping up around 2 or so weeks after the game came out...\n\nThe rest of this review is based on my own personal feelings as someone who has played as sorcery based classes since demon souls. As for the actual gameplay my major complaint, besides enemies following the tired formula of have infiite stamina to bash you with, is how bad sorcery has it this time around. No one was asking for from to make the game easy for us(don't understand how it ever was. Dodging skills were a must in agressive boss fights and pvp). However with 90% of the bosses in this game being aggressive and spells damage being nerfed hard, it makes boss fight needlessly difficult and maybe even a little unfair. Playing as melee, Spell damage has been given really odd base requirements before the it become decent. Starting at 60 int is where you'll start to see the damage accel at. Keep in mind that in previous souls game you maxed out at 60 if you were hardcore sorcery otherwise 50 was perfectly fine at you're still dangerous. Remember how soul spear and the crystal spells(bar homing crystal in dks1) were good? Yeah not so much in this game. Incredibly slow and in most cases outclassed by the arrow spells. I started the game as a spellsword thanks to some people on reddit I was able to see just how jacked sorcery really was. To start  my Dex was 25 and int 15 with base class being merc. Casting magic weapon wields an extra 50 points of dmg at best. I don't remember these results in the first 2 games. In DK1 with mild point allocation I remember seeing around 100 points of extra damage on an unupgraded weapon. In this game I deal with one swing 200~210 per swing on a normal enemy with a +3 Uchi. Respec to 31 dex and 21 int damage went from 263 to 290 with magic weapon. This was done as apparently you don't see minor returns on int until at least 20. So that's my opinion on this game from a spell slinger pov. I wanted to love this game. Really I did. But I have completely lost faith in from's ability to make an anti-cheat system that's worth a damn and that sorcery will stop being completely eclipsed by other styles of play.

First while fighting the Dancer I repeatedly attacked her and had my attacks bounce off her as if I were hitting a wall or something and doing no damage.  I got her down to almost nothing before dying, had the attacks I would have landed if not for this bug actually went through I would have killed her before then.  I had to then go on to fight her for like another hour before beating her finally.  Here's proof. https://www.twitch.tv/ultrakrampus/v/60612659

Second while fighting Champion Gundyr when the boss was at critical health the bug that gets a random input stuck(so say you run in one direction without pressing the button and if you press another direction your character freezes in place) prevented me from moving as I was trying to move in the opposite direction, this got me killed.  GG fromsoft and by GG I mean GIT GUD.

The story delivery and writing are also amateur as ♥♥♥♥.  Game assumes you're going to be doing all this ♥♥♥♥.  Oh youll be needing to go here and do this and this."  Why?  why would you assume I would even care?  They do no work to set up why you would have any motivation to do this the only motivation to play the game is becasue its a souls game and you want to murder things."

reviewText:
The perfection of dark souls saga.

PROS:
> World map, it's better than the one in DS1 (best one before DS3).
> Items, there are fewer than previous games but with more relevance.
> Combat perfection.
> It's more challenging than DS1 and DS2.

CONS:
> Boss fights are harder than DS1 and DS2, but easier than Bloodborne.
> Shorter than previous game (less than 50 hours for a complete first run).

reviewText:
Honestly kinda' meh. I don't see myself pouring thousands of hours into this game like the previous ones, hell I'm barely breaking bloodborne hours right now and this is way better than that thing sitting on my ps4. Was pretty fun the first week though, lots of summons and invasions, everyone was experimenting, but now it's all meta: gr8 swords, spear, or estoc. No variety, no fun moves. Pve is pretty eh too, plays fine, I suppose, but isn't pulling me into it. Enemy aggression is bipolar, drop rates, at least for me, despite buffing the stat, are abysmal. Seriously, 2 hours trying to get a machete just to try it. Sub optimal. I'm sure plenty of folks will love this game though, just like with bloodborne, just like with 2, yada-yada. If you started later in the series, or with bb (the mistake) then you'll love this, if you started with one, eh, you'll still probably like it. Not for me though. I'll try and sum it up below.

Enemy aggression: honestly, they're either going ham or they're motionless, seemingly regardless of my position in relation to them. Checked streamers, youtube, everyone elses game seems fine, but my world is always like this. Who knows.

Drop rates: several hours for a machete, several more for a dagger in the woods, tons waiting for a silver knight shield, only to find out the items above weren't even worth it. For real, long sword + Lothric knight shield is all you'll need, nothing comes close to that combos usefulness. Even the cool quickstep ♥♥♥♥♥ is weak in comparison and that ♥♥♥♥♥ is cool af.

hackers: summoned a few without knowing, invaded a few without knowing, was invaded by a few without knowing. Tell tale sign for anyone interested, they won't have a walk animation, they'll just sorta...float around. This is also sign of a ♥♥♥♥♥ connection though, so be wary. Pro-tip, don't pvp right now, if you wanna co-op, use a password with one friend, any more than that and you'll be invaded.

oddly short: now most souls games can be speed run pretty swiftly, like DKS2 unpatched can be done in like twenty minutes. This thing...about an hour, hour and a half, potentially less post NG simply due to how many bosses are, well, optional. Which is fine, but that alone is pretty bloodborne-y and well I hated that game so lets leave it at that.

Meta: whether in pvp or pve you'll hit a wall with what is useful vs what is fun. Useful: longsword and a 100% melee cut shield. What's fun, manakin claws (holy ♥♥♥♥, dude) but sadly, not useful. As you level up even the infusions are ♥♥♥♥-poor: heavy and sharp are a joke compared to quality (usually) raw is useless as the pure damage up is still less than the BASE scaling benefits (literally at lvl 1 a raw longsword is weaker than a standard longsword due to the scaling. If you infuse it with quality scaling it becomes even more of a joke). Fire and Deep are useless as there are scaling based alternatives, and how defenses work with enemies in the game you may as well, again, just use quality or no infusion at all and just apply buff items. Pvp-wise, hope you like the estoc and greatswords because that is literally all you'll see outside of the occasional spear. Oh, and the target shield, everyone has one of those. Maybe as things get patched the metas will lessen but I highly doubt it as DKS1 and DKS2 metas are still going strong years later.

Upped AI + upped damage: now, upgraded enemy AI is the thing of dreams, it makes enemies plan their attacks, strafe, parry, riposte, backstab, backpeddle to heal or get allies, lure you, use consumable ffs, it's amazing, but you know what isn't? Getting run over by a truck then it gliding away in a very graceful animation that messes with my emotions. A key feature I feel has been lost to FROM was that enemy placement and moveset variety are what made their enemies hard, making them hit like trucks is what made bloodborne a joke. Especially when you get into the flailing type enemies, which are most of the humanoid ones, as they hit like trucks and stunlock you...as there is no poise system. Who knows though, maybe this is due to me trying to use some of those nifty armor sets FROM litered the game with...perhaps I was supposed to just wear the knights set on every character forever.

Poise: you've probably seen this pop up a bit, poise isn't in the game. Armor has a poise rating, but...well, it means about as much as my review does: nothing. You might as well just fashion it up and cross your fingers that you don't get hit by a combo. There is a way to bypass this: greatswords. They give you hyper armor, which can act like poise as it keeps you stable midswing even if you're getting jumped by several enemies...just hope you have enough HP (trucks *cough* trucks).

Useless weapons: mentioned this in the meta section, but it requires restating, almost every weapon you pick up will be inferior to something like the longsword or battleaxe (hell even some battleaxes are useless too!) they're either too big to handle in most environments, too short to effectively reach enemies (despite the sick af quickstep or other unique weapon arts) or they're just not practical (i.e. consume huge amounts of stamina per swing or just don't deal enough damage compared to their atk time and stamina use). In other words, your starting gear will be the best gear unless you aren't the knight or herald (arguably the assassin too).

Weapon arts: they killed dual wielding for this? I don't think I've touched the weapon arts for most weapons since I picked them up for the first time: they're useless. The longswords? Breaks guards...so does the kick. The estocs pierces shields (but can be parried) just kick (no parries). Some shields only let you use weapon arts (great for the quickstep...and the like three weapons which use it...the most useful weapon art in the game...) some let you parry (the small shields) and some let you try (the mid shields) others..well...you sorta give a shove with them...often really slowly and incredibly telegraphed.

Quickstep: jfc this is only on a handful of weapons yet it is singlehandedly the best weaponart in the game, it lets you dash right after the strike period of an animation (something you can't do with the roll) and it also keeps you close to your target. It's fabulous but also only on the worst weapons: three daggers, and a claw set (as far as I've found). Seriously, give me a weapon with better damage, or reach, or SCALING ffs that uses it.

Heal aid: you can cast this basic heal spell with 8 faith...but the lowest req talisman is 10 faith... (not multi faceted catalsyts, kids, those are too late into things for this to still be useful outside of low HP runs) . Seems like an oversight, at the very least.

Let's talk about some nice things though, people like those...well, not on the internet anyway.

Level design is nice, got a lotta' quick pathes you can take to speedrun this thing. Animations are nice, usually, like when you dash with the quickstep (I'm salty) or roll off the ground b/c that carried over from BB...not so much though when a sitting enemy you ambushed is, mid attack by you, suddenly on their feet and unleashing a several hit combo that you can no longer get out of because your two attacks are qued ahead of your roll (because that wasn't annoying in the earlier games) particularly annoying when combined with the ever present incorrect input read (remember that from Dark Souls 1? I do. It's here now too, yay!) Mind you, it could be that literally all four of the controllers I have available suffer from some odd software/hardware issue, but I kinda doubt that as they work fine elsewhere (games and console) yay FROM you never cease to...find a way to rehash even old mechanical errors.

Well...I guess I didn't really have anything nice to say...uh...it looks...nice? I guess? But that's sorta just what happens when a series progresses: get prettier, polish mechanics, and try not to ♥♥♥♥ it all up.

reviewText:
Dark Souls III is a good game in and of itself. Exploration is a huge part of the journey and the reason a first playthrough takes so many hours. Scanning every nook and cranny, dying horribly to everything and starting over.

PC port runs excellent on my system (i5 4690k, 16GB, GTX 970). I've probably experienced 2 crashes in the 80 or so hours I've been playing.

Level design is remarkable, though I did note a trend in This door doesn't open from this side" spoilering an obvious shortcut later. A bit too many bonfires for my taste too

reviewText:
I have played all DS series and I feel DS 3 still managed to overjoy me. Great boss battles, challenging enemies, great scenarios, etc. The game itself hasnt changed much compared to its previous versions, but it stills feel pretty unique and the game mechanics have improved/evolved.

Compared to older Dark Souls games:
- Faster combat (movement feels a bit faster).
- Casting and proyectile animations are MUCH faster.
- Durability isnt an issue anymore.
- Improved covenant system.
- All weapons have skills/stances.

If you liked previous DS titles this is a must buy.
If you are willing to get immersed into the Dark Souls world for the first time, this is still a solid choice and be prepared to die a lot :)

reviewText:
I'm one of those heretics that likes DS2 better than DS3. Sure, DS3 is a lot cleaner and has smarter level design, but I feel like DS2 actually had way more content then DS3.

Anyways, DS3 is still a fantastic game. Let me give you guys a bit of a quick tip so that you can familiarize yourself with the game.

-Get Astora sword and infuse it with Raw stone. This will make a best weapon for PvE that will last you until end of the game.
-Buy the white sign soapstone and help people when you are in a new area. This will help you get used to that area and the enemies there
-If you disconnect from player invasion 20 times, you will be locked out from coop. So do it at your own risk.

reviewText: Absolutely one of the best games I've played in years. The ammount of variety will keep the game fresh and interesting for years to come, not to mention the addicting PVP online play and unique co-op that is deliciously unpredictable. The challenge of the game makes you want to be better and rewards you for doing so, and expolration for secret areas are laden with diffculty and epic loot. If you're new to the Souls series or a returning champion, this is the game for you. If you're up to the challenge then absolutley get this game. I would not be suprized if this won game of the year for 2016.\n\n~ PRAISE THE SOUP! ~

reviewText:
The perfection of dark souls saga.

PROS:
> World map, it's better than the one in DS1 (best one before DS3).
> Items, there are fewer than previous games but with more relevance.
> Combat perfection.
> It's more challenging than DS1 and DS2.

CONS:
> Boss fights are harder than DS1 and DS2, but easier than Bloodborne.
> Shorter than previous game (less than 50 hours for a complete first run).

reviewText: Dark Souls 3 is the most polished Dark Souls game yet because it has obviously learned from the mistakes of Dark Souls 1 & 2. And yet Dark Souls 3 is also the least interesting Dark Souls game because there are few weird and strange enemy and encounters.  I love Dark Souls because you must defeat difficult enemy by learning the game and taking risks so you can be rewarded. Well, Dark Souls 3 doesn't have many super difficult enemy, most of the game is pretty similar and there very few interesting rewards.\n\nUnlike in Dark Souls 1 & 2, I wouldn't say playing online is recommended anymore. There is maybe two or three difficult bosses if you are offline only.  When you are playing online in ember" form (aka human-form or unhollowed)
date: you rarely get invaded and you can easily summon skilled players to be your allies so you can destroy any invader & boss. It's not interesting when you summon a Sunbro ally who defeats the boss while you watch. I would have to place my summon sign so I could help others defeat that boss a few times so I could feel some satisfaction from the boss fight. And as always
recommended: using a gamepad is strongly recommended.\n\nTL;DR Dark Souls is more Dark Souls and I cannot say I didn't enjoy Dark Souls 3 even though it is the least interesting Dark Souls game. For Dark Souls newbies I would recommend you try Dark Souls 2
hoursPlayed:
maybe Dark Souls 1 if you want a challenge. And for Dark Souls Veterans:

Pro- The world is more open than DS2 (less linear)
- Weapons are very balanced
- convenant variety
- offline friendly
- very few rage inducing enemy

Cons- very few rage inducing enemy
- the easiest Dark Souls game
- the shortest Dark Souls game
- The least variety of Bosses
- there aren't any serious consequences to the covenants
- All magic is mostly useless for damage until you have very high-level sorcery
- Magic is far too slow for PvP
- online friendly - a few connectivity improvements since DS2
- The world isn't as open as DS1
- Camera is still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥"

reviewText:
The definitive Dark Souls experience, recommended? Absolutely. Spoiler free review.

The great- Stunning and smart level design, there are ALWAYS clues for the secrets if you pay attention, there is often a more convenient and less obvious path to take.
- Bosses: mostly different from each other, multiple phases. Very few bosses gave me real trouble as a solo player, while still being fair fights. Praise the lack of gank squads!
- Soundtrack, what else to say?
- It took me over 50 hours to finish the first run, 50!

The good- Enemy AI. The PvE offers a good challenge also outside of bosses: knights won't let you circle around them as easily, they will tackle you differently depending on their weapons and your offensive/defensive stance, while beasts will mindlessly rush you down and screw your life if they get an opening.
- Tons of weapons and armors, many new infusions for every kind of build.
- High amount of references and throwbacks.
- Very populated online, it had some problems in the beginning but it seems stable at this point. There is an easy password system to engage in jolly co-operation with your friends of any level.
- Weapon arts are the cherry on top of my favourite ARPG combat system ever.

The meh"- Too many references? Too much fanservice? I personally enjoyed all of them
date: but your mileage may vary.\n\nThe bad- PvP balance and poise: pretty much every heavy weapon can be parried and poise doesn't work (actually
hoursPlayed: so running tanky builds will get you nowhere in a world ruled by rapiers and short swords.\n\nWe didn't get Bloodborne on PC
voteText: we got this instead. PvE is a 10/10 and I recommend it at full price
helpfulPercent: but people who live for PvP may not have their best time here."

reviewText:
I invade a dude's world and see I have a friend.
We go off and try to find the host's location.
Host springs out from a corner in a suprise attack.
It was not that surprising, no one is harmed.
Following the failed surprise attack, a wacky chase scene!
We both lose sight of host, and my buddy decides to try and find them.
I get an idea to lure the host out.
I decide to wait patiently underneath a giant's crotch.
Host notices me and uses seed of Giant Tree.
Giant suddenly doesn't like that I am under his crotch.
Host gets exposed when using item, wacky chase continues.
Host goes down the big ladder to the Water Reserve.
We follow, and have a small scuffle with the host.
Host hides behind a pillar.
We do not pursue the host upon realizing the two Crocowolves would aggro if we did.
Everyone sits around for awhile.
I get another idea.
I take out my bow and arrow.
I shoot an arrow right above the host's head.
Host gestures, presumably in mockery that I missed my shot.
I did not miss my shot, the Crocowolf right past the host can attest to this.
Buddy takes the cue to make a tactical retreat up the ladder.
Crocowolf lunges at me as I climb up the ladder, inflicting some damage.
Host continues laying on the ground.
Crocowolf loses interest in me as I ascend further, interrupting the Host's nap.
Host tries to knock some sense into the Crocowolf to convince it to chase me instead.
Both Crocowolves are now chasing the host.
My buddy and I both watch the spectacle from a high point on the ladder.
I sip my Estus Flask as I hear the host scream in agony upon death.

Overall Rating: Just As Planned" Out of 10"
